title: Mortgage rates rise despite the Bank of Canada rate cuts: Mortgage Broker
description: Despite the Bank of Canada's push to lower overnight lending rates to near zero, Canada's big banks have actually been raising their mortgage rates to pad their profits.  Mortgage broker Joe Sammut weighs in.

title: 'There's a lot of fear' about defaults, raising mortgage rates even as BoC cuts: RateSpy's McLister
description: Mortgage rates have not been responding in lockstep with the Bank of Canada's rate cuts as the big banks become more wary of the risks of lending in the current economic environment. For more on this, BNN Bloomberg spoke with Rob McLister, founder of RateSpy.com

title: Five-year mortgage rates could fall 10 basis point in two to three weeks: Rates.ca
description: Global bond yields are plunging to historic lows, raising the prospects for lower mortgage rates for house-hungry Canadians. For perspective on this and why he thinks five-year rates could fall another 10 basis points in a number of weeks, BNN Bloomberg spoke with Rob McLister, mortgage editor at Rates.ca.

title: How worries about the new coronavirus are pushing Canadian mortgage rates lower
description: BNN Bloomberg's Greg Bonnell speaks with James Laird, co-founder of Ratehub.ca and president of CanWise Financial, about how fears surrounding the coronavirus are impacting mortgages rates here in Canada.

title: Higher rates fail to materialize, keeping mortgage rates low
description: The higher rates many feared to start 2019 failed to materialize, keeping mortgage rates low. For more on this, BNN Bloomberg spoke with Rob McLister, founder of RateSpy.com.

title: 'Very questionable' politicians can make it easier to get credit: McLister
description: The benchmark Canadian five-year yield has been surging, and the banks could be quick to respond by raising their mortgage rates. For more on this and why mortgage rates could rise as much as half a per cent, BNN Bloomberg spoke with Rob McLister, founder of RateSpy.com.

title: Australian Banks Face Competition Inquiry Into Mortgage Rates
description: Oct.13 -- Australia’s major lenders are facing a new investigation, this time into why they haven’t passed on the RBA’s rate cuts in full. Bloomberg’s Peter Vercoe reports on “Bloomberg Daybreak: Asia.”

title: Denmark mortgage rates go negative, unlikely Canada would ever follow: RateSpy
description: Prospective homeowners in Denmark can now secure a negative rate mortgage, as central banks go deeper into negative territory. For perspective on this and why he doesn't think Canada will ever follow, BNN Bloomberg spoke with Robert McLister, founder of RateSpy.com.

title: Mortgage market flips as 5-year fixed falls below variable
description: Gyrations in the bond market are turning the mortgage market upside down, with five-year fixed rates falling below the variable. For more on this, BNN Bloomberg speaks with James Laird, co-founder of Ratehub.ca

title: No Bank of Canada rate cut until mid-2020: Economist
description: David Doyle, North American economist and Canadian market strategist at Macquarie Group, says economic conditions will allow the Bank of Canada to defy conventional wisdom in moving on interest rates and not be quick to follow the Federal Reserve. Doyle expects two cuts from the Fed this year, but says the  Bank of Canada will likely not cut until the middle of 2020.

title: Fixed mortgage rates set to decline further: RateSpy's McLister
description: Plunging bond yields are changing the mortgage rate outlook for Canadians. BNN Bloomberg speaks with Rob McLister, founder of RateSpy.com, about what consumers can expect when it comes to borrowing costs.

title: Spring mortgage war begins as big banks cut some rates
description: Canada's big banks are beginning to trim their lending rates amid a swoon in the underlying Canadian five-year bond yield, kicking off the spring mortgage war. For more on this, BNN Bloomberg spoke with Rob McLister, founder of RateSpy.com.

title: Big Canadian banks start trimming 5-year fixed mortgage rates
description: Rob McLister of RateSpy.com tells us where to find the best deals on mortgage rates and what to expect this spring as the big banks begin taking a scalpel to their five-year fixed mortgage rates.

title: Expect downward pressure on fixed mortgage rates: Ratehub co-founder
description: James Laird, co-founder of Ratehub Inc. and president of CanWise Financial, says the Bank of Canada's reaction to Alberta's output cut for oil production will likely mean better fixed mortgage rates in the coming weeks.

title: Fixed or variable? How to play rising mortgage rates
description: Rob McLister of RateSpy gives his take on rising borrowing costs for Canadian home owners.

title: Higher mortgage rates hit housing
description: Home prices in Toronto may have dipped slightly, but higher  mortgage rates continue to make housing less affordable. BNN Bloomberg looks at the state of housing affordability in Canada with Robert Hogue, senior economist at RBC

title: Pattie Lovett-Reid: Mortgage rates in Canada march higher
description: New data suggests that fixed-rate mortgages have hit a high not seen in four years. CTV’s Chief Financial Commentator Pattie Lovett-Reid has more.

title: Rising rates pose threat to Canada's 3.4 million subprime borrowers
description: With household debt levels at record highs and rates on the rise, there may be trouble on the horizon for Canada’s 3.4 million subprime borrowers. Chris Fournier of Bloomberg News breaks it all down.

title: Personal Investor: The mortgage market is getting ugly
description: Dale Jackson discusses how the burden for homeowners has multiplied.

title: Homebuyers facing higher mortgage rates as RBC, TD hike 5-year fixed term
description: RateSpy.com founder Rob McLister joins The Business News for a panel chat on mortgage rates after TD raised its five-year fixed rate.

title: How the bond-yield surge could impact your mortgage rates
description: RateSpy.com founder Rob McLister joins BNN to lay out how rising bond yields could impact your mortgage rates.

title: Rising rates and the impact on your finances
description: Kelley Keehn, personal finance educator and consumer advocate for the Financial Planning Standards Council, look at how rising borrowing costs could impact people's personal finances.

title: Rising rates and what it means for your mortgage
description: Samantha Brookes, CEO of Mortgages of Canada, looks at the rising cost of borrowing and the impact it may have on the housing market.

title: Some homeownership dreams dying as mortgage rates rise
description: Following a fresh round of mortgage rate hikes ahead of an anticipated rate increase at the Bank of Canada, we examine the challenges ahead for aspiring first-time homebuyers in Canada. Rob Carrick, personal finance columnist at The Globe and Mail, says for some first-time buyers — especially in the Toronto and Vancouver regions — the dream of homeownership is fading away.

title: The impact of rising rates on your mortgage
description: James Laird, co-founder of RateHub, looks at the possibility of a rate hike next week by the Bank of Canada and the potential impact on the housing industry.

title: Canadian banks gain share in mortgage market after rule changes: Mortgage broker
description: David Larock, President and Mortgage Broker at Integrated Mortgage Planners discusses why Canadian banks are gaining share in the mortgage market and how further Bank of Canada rate moves could have an impact.

title: Why homebuyers should consider a fixed mortgage rate over variable
description: RateHub Co-founder James Laird discusses fixed versus variable mortgage rates after the Bank of Canada signals it could be gearing up for an interest rate increase.

title: Fixed vs. variable: The best approach to mortgage rates
description: Rob McLister, founder of Ratespy.com, looks at the current mortgage rate environment as the spring selling season approaches.

title: New mortgage rates good for banks, bad for borrowers: RateSpy
description: Rob McLister, founder of RateSpy.com, joins BNN to discuss the mortgage trends coming in 2017.

title: Cracks form in Canada's housing foundation
description: Peter Norman, vice president and chief economist at Altus Group, joins House Money to discuss some of the recent commentary about weakness in Canada's housing market.

title: Rising U.S. consumer sentiment helps lift retail stocks
description: U.S. economic growth expectations have soared since Trump's election victory. David Prince of Harbinger Capital Markets Research, joins BNN to take a look at how increased consumer sentiment has impacted retail stocks and the knock-on effect rising U.S. yields will have on the Canadian mortgage market.

title: MoneyTalk: What rising mortgage rates mean for Canadians
description: Don Campbell, senior analyst at Real Estate Investment Network, looks at rising mortgage rates in Canada and the impact on potential buyers and the housing market.

title: The Trump effect: What rising rates mean for Canada's housing market
description: Mortgage rates are starting to creep higher in the wake of Donald Trump's election. Craig Alexander, chief economist at the Conference Board of Canada, joins BNN's House Money to discuss what this means for Canada's housing market and the broader economy.

title: RBC boosts mortgage rates as Trump presidency roils bond market
description: Rob McLister, founder at RateSpy.com, joins BNN for thoughts on RBC's changes to mortgage rates. He also explains why he thinks the other banks will follow suit.

title: Trump presidency drives mortgage rates in Canada
description: Royal Bank of Canada announced it is raising its discounted three-, four- and five-year fixed mortgage rates between 25 and 40 basis points, as bond markets react to a Trump presidency. BNN’s Greg Bonnell has more on how the President-elect could impact your homeownership costs.

title: RBC lifts discounted mortgage rates by as much as 40 basis
description: Royal Bank of Canada is raising its discounted three, four and five-year fixed mortgage rates between 25 and 40 basis points as of Thursday. CTV’s Chief Financial Commentator Pattie Lovett-Reid breaks down the details.

title: Trump presidency means now is the best time to lock in a mortgage: RateSpy
description: Robert McLister, founder of RateSpy.com, talks about how the shifting bond market resulting from the election of Donald Trump could make fixed-rate mortgages more appealing in Canada.

title: Cost of new mortgage rules? Fewer mortgage options, says McLister
description: BNN speaks with Rob McLister of RateSpy.com. He says regulators have seriously hit families in the pocketbook. He talks about the ways in which the average Canadian will be affected.

title: Ways to lower your mortgage
description: Patricia Lovett-Reid looks at steps you can take to lower the interest paid on your mortgage.

title: Canadian homeowners using Airbnb to curb rising mortgage costs
description: A growing number of Canadians are using Airbnb to supplement  their mortgage payments as home prices in Canada’s hottest housing markets continue to rise up according to Aaron Zifkin, Airbnb's Regional Director for North American Operations. He spoke to BNN’s Jon Erlichman about the company’s growth in Canada.

title: Pattie Lovett-Reid: Bad dates vs. mortgage rates
description: ANALYSIS: We talk a lot about shopping around for a mortgage and the benefits of a fixed mortgage vs. variable rates all the time on BNN. But a PC Financial report says nearly half of Canadians would rather discuss their dating history with a partner over mortgages with their broker.

title: No move at the Bank of Canada
description: The Bank of Canada did not budge on interest rates today and Frances Donald, Senior Economist, Manulife Asset Management, says it was the right move.  She says increased fiscal stimulus is what's missing in efforts to strengthen the economy and the BoC should stay on hold for the rest of the year.

title: Online interest in variable rate mortgages is up: RateHub founder
description: Alyssa Furtado, Founder and CEO, RateHub.ca discusses Canadian consumer trends in mortgages and rising interest in variable rate mortgages.

title: Did the Royal Bank really need to hike mortgage rates?
description: BNN Market Commentator Andrew McCreath was shcoked to learn of Royal Bank's plans to hike mortgage rates. He asks whether this is another sign of limited prospects for bottom line growth.

title: Andrew McCreath: It's not North Korea, but China that’s roiling markets
description: Morning Call: BNN Commentator Andrew McCreath says China's currency market is the biggest factor driving markets lower today and that things could get even worse if the speculators trying to cheapen the yuan get their way. He explains why.

title: RBC set to raise mortgage rates
description: Royal Bank of Canada is set to raise rates on several of its mortgages. Andrew Bell has the details.

title: Rates on several mortgages will go up at RBC
description: Royal Bank of Canada is set to raise rates on several of its mortgages — the latest in a series of changes to the mortgage industry that could help cool the housing market this year.

title: Vancouver home values surge 15-25%
description: The value of a single detached home in Vancouver surged as much as 25% over the course of a year, according to BC Assessment. For more on whether the housing market will continue to heat up, BNN is joined by Jason Grant, Regional Assessor, BC Assessment.

title: Bank of Canada holds key rate steady at 0.50%
description: The Bank of Canada is keeping its key interest rate unchanged at 0.50 percent. Benjamin Tal, Deputy Chief Economist, CIBC Capital Markets gives his reaction.

title: Five ways the Liberals could Impact your mortgage
description: The new Liberal government could move the levers of the Canadian mortgage market. For the five key ways Trudeau's party could move the needle, BNN is joined by Rob McLister, Editor, Canadian Mortgage Trends
